The performances are absolutely great in this film as well as Billy Bob Thornton gives his best performance ever (better than U-Turn, Monster's ball, Bad Santa, Intolerable Cruelty or Armageddon). Natalie Canderday, Lucas Black, JT Walsh and Robert Duvall were also great. John Ritter and Dwight Yoakam gave the films best performances along with Thornton. This is a great drama, a masterpiece from Billy Bob Thornton, a true triumph in film-making. 10/10 #49 on my list of all-time favorite films

He was arrested at age 12 for brutally slaughtering his mom and her lover with a sling blade. 25 years later, Karl Childers (Billy Bob Thornton) tells his story to some people before he is released from a mental hospital. After that, he moves back to his town in Millsberg, Arkansas. While there, he develops a friendship with Frank Wheatly (Lucas Black) and Frank's mother (Natalie Canerday). They invite Karl to stay with them at their house. He accepts and moves in immediatley. But, while there, he meets the mother's boyfriend Doyle (Dwight Yoakum). He learns that Doyle is abusive and is a drunk cheater. So now, Karl is reflecting to his past to what is going on in the present.Written and directed by Billy Bob Thornton (Monster's Ball), Sling Blade is one movie that will change people's lives. It deals with serious issues and is a movie to be taken seriously.Rated R for:  Graphic Language, Strong Sexual Content/Dialogue, Brutal Violence

reviews.review_title: When a murderer is the likable protagonist, mmm-hmm
reviews.content: A simple, slow, seemingly pensive man (Billy Bob Thornton) is released from a mental hospital in central Arkansas after 30 years and gets a job fixing lawnmowers. He makes friends with a boy & his mother (Natalie Canerday) and they let him live in their garage, but the mother's abusive boyfriend presents a problem (Dwight Yoakam). John Ritter is on hand as the mother's gay best friend."Sling Blade" (1996) is a small town drama with a memorable central character (if I didn't know beforehand that Thornton played the role, I wouldn't have recognized him). The characters and their situations smack of real life while the unhurried story is interesting enough. There are well-done moments of meditation and revelation, as well as touching ones.It's a tad overlong, however, and the politically correct glorification of Vaughan (Ritter) is eye-rolling. Karl (Thornton) observes that "The Bible says two men ought not lay together. But I don't reckon the Good Lord would send anybody like you to Hades." Yet his opining doesn't mean much since he candidly acknowledges elsewhere that he doesn't understand a lot of the Scriptures, not to mention his foolish predilection for murder to solve mundane problems. He should stick to fixing lawnmowers and eating them French fried potaters, mmm-hmm.The film runs 2 hours, 15 minutes, and was shot in Benton & nearby Haskell, Arkansas, which are about 20-30 minutes southwest of Little Rock.GRADE: B-

reviews.review_title: One-note repetition drew critical praise, but makes for a boring evening
reviews.content: Many of my friends loved this, but I found it pretentious and boring.  Only breath of fresh air was Dwight Yoakam's realistic performance as abusive boyfriend.  But, this movie celebrates the ordinary to the point of watching seeds grow and powder dry.  It might be great art, but it's not my idea of entertainment.

reviews.review_title: An Excellent Tale Of a Mentally Challenged Man Trying To Make His Way In Life
reviews.content: This movie came out in 1996 and I wish I had caught it earlier on, but alas, I was only able to see it this year in 2022. What first caught my attention about this film were the scenes I recently found on YouTube.I was captivated by Billy Bob Thornton's performance as the mentally challenged man, Karl Childers and his attempt to fit into society again after being locked up in a sanitarium since childhood. I knew then I had to watch it in its entirety so I ordered the DVD online and wasn't disappointed.This is an extremely touching movie about someone with mentally challenged issues who got sent to a mental hospital after committing a violent crime as a boy. Several years later he's deemed fit to return to society and he goes back to his hometown.His adjustment to life beyond the walls of the mental institution aren't easy though. He wanders around aimlessly and even has uncertainty about ordering from a hamburger stand until he decides to try some of those "French fried potaters".He eventually runs into and befriends a boy named Frank, wonderfully played by Lucas Black, who immediately takes a liking to Karl and likes the way he talks. That's the most touching part about this film was their friendship.Karl eventually meets Frank's mother, a sweet and kind hearted woman, as well as her "best friend", an openly gay man who also happens to be her boss at the local dollar store. John Ritter gives an excellent performance as Vaughan Cunningham, the gay friend who tries to be secretive about his lifestyle even though the whole town already knew about it. He also seemed to act apologetic about it as well. That was evident when he revealed his gay status to Karl with paranoia and discomfort as they had lunch together.The major highlight though was country music superstar, Dwight Yoakam's performance as Doyle, the arrogant and bad tempered boyfriend to Frank's mother. He's a total heel and makes it evidently so with his domineering attitude and extremely insulting way of talking.You can't help, but despise him, especially the cruel comments he makes to Frank and the derogatory way he treats Frank's mother. That evidently showed the serious problems that laid in that household and there were concerns, especially from Vaughn, about the safety of Frank and his mom.Karl moves into their garage and gets a welcoming reception to that except, of course, for Doyle, who wants to take total control of the household and he proves it with his obsessive demands on telling people to "Get Out!" whenever he felt like it. Even if it was his girlfriend's place and not his. That causes major problems right there and Karl seems oblivious to it at first, but later, you can see he totally understood.This is indeed a beautiful and heartwarming movie with an excellent cast and a totally original story. Billy Bob Thornton is absolutely convincing as the mentally challenged Karl with his gruff way of talking and his habit of saying, "Um..Hmm" after anything he says. He truly is a memorable and unforgettable character. To sum up my review of this excellent film, all I can say is "Um..Hmm".

reviews.review_title: WITHOUT A DOUBT THE BEST FILM I'VE EVER SEEN
reviews.content: I cannot believe I am just now seeing this film for the first time. I recently rented the DVD of "Bad Santa" and in one of the special features they made reference to "Sling Blade". It had a clip of B.B.T. and John Ritter. The clip was about one minute long and in that one minute i was cracking up. I was curious about the film having never heard of it before. The next day I had to rent it. This was the first movie I have ever watched and said to myself "damn this guy deserves an Oscar". Billy Bob Thortons role was by far the best portrayal of a character I have ever seen. I have seen many great actors in many great roles, but I don't think I have ever seen a more intriguing performance. His performance of Karl was absolutely incredible. If I did not know that Karl was being portrayed by Billy Bob I never would have guessed it. It wasn't like most movies where you see the actor and know their acting. I was so swept away by the acting and story of this film I almost forgot I was watching a movie.Judging from the clip I had seen the night before on Bad Santa I was expecting the film to be a comedy. I was very wrong. While the film did make me laugh a few times, it also had me close to tears at times. The film was masterfully done. Billy Bob's writing and directing were also phenomenal. The rest of the cast was great as well. John Ritter, Dwight Yoakum, and the boy who played Frank all gave great performances. I am a big fan of Dwight and his music but hell before the movie was over I wanted him dead LOL.I have read some of the things other users have said about this film. I think a few of them are very narrow minded. Some I think have read more into it than what was really there. There was a lot of stereo typing in the movie but it came only from Doyle. Whats a better way to paint a picture of a bad guy in a small town? I thought the movie displayed southerners to have a lot of heart. Hell these people took in Karl with open arms and gave him work and shelter and he was a complete stranger to them.This movie had no explosions, no special fx, no machine guns, no gratuitous nudity, and none of the other Hollywood gimmicks used to put people into the theatre. This movie was just a superb example of film making. This film exhausted all of ur senses. It made you laugh, it made you cry, it made you feel the suspense, but most of all it made you think. I highly recommend it to anyone who has not yet seen it. I give this movie a 12.

"Sling Blade" is a very well-made movie about the friendship between a grown man who is in some senses a child in his mind, and a young boy in desperate need of a father figure.Billy Bob Thornton's portrayal of Karl, who's been in a state hospital since the age of twelve, is sensational. He brings depth and credibility to his character. Karl's helplessness is heartbreaking. And the friendship with the young boy Frank, played by Lucas Black, is very believable and touching.Thornton is truly a very talented actor, writer and director. This movie will make you happy and sad all in once, and nobody will be untouched by the power in Thornton's story-telling and acting. A truly wonderful, heartwarming, and touching movie.

reviews.review_title: Great acting makes this movie worthwhile!
reviews.content: What would this movie be without the brilliant acting performance of Billy Bob Thornton?  The plot is pretty thin with no real twists or turns.  It's just simply about a mentally retarded man who's trying to fit back into society after being locked for committing a murder.  It focuses mostly on his relationship with a young boy ,his mother, and her abusive boyfriend played very well by Dwight Yoakam.  The movie really drags on toward the middle with nothing significant really happening.  Any other movie like this I probably would have turned off.  However, the acting of Billy Bob Thornton really makes this movie worth watching.  It was just so amazing to watch how he portrays every aspect of this character: his facial expressions, his speech mannerisms, his walk, etc.  If you want to see a movie with great performances, then rent this one.

Billy Bob Thornton is so amazing in this movie. He looses himself so completely that it is almost impossible to tell it is actually Billy Bob in the movie. One of the best acting jobs I have ever seen because he never seemed to be acting at all. I believe every person who wishes to become an actress or an actor should be required to watch this movie and learn from one of the best in the business. Everyone did a great job in this movie. But, I know from experience when you have an awesome actor in the lead everyone else works to bring themselves up to their level. This movie is a must see.

reviews.review_title: Reckon You Make Me Some Biscuits!
reviews.content: Sling Blade is the best Drama movie I've ever seen. Billy Bob Thornton wrote this movie, directed it and even played in it! I'll have to say this is his best performance and he pulls it off very well. He plays as Karl Childers in the movie. The movie is about Karl getting out of mental hospital and going back to the real world. He got put in the nut house for murdering his mom and her lover. So Karl gets out and makes friends with a boy named Frank. They become good friends in the movie and Karl moves in with them. Things go great until Frank's mean step dad Doyle shows up. Karl is fed up with the way Doyle treats his family, so Karl takes action! Sling Blade has some very funny lines too. Karl says some of the funniest things. I laughed when he said quote in the movie to John Ritter's character. I don't reckon you have to go with women to be a good daddy to a boy. You been real square-dealing' with me. The Bible says two men ought not lay together. But I don't reckon the Good Lord would send anybody like you to Hades. He loves those biscuits with mustard too. This is one great movie though; I highly recommend it to any movie fan. It's funny, realistic, sad, and weird at times too. R.I.P. John Ritter! I reckon I give this here movie a 10/10

reviews.review_title: Hollywood has no clue about what's relevant.
reviews.content: i thought this movie was slow-moving--not in an enjoyable way, either--and worst of all, predictable. i found myself hoping that the 'twist' ending would turn out to be some other kind of twist because you can see where this movie is heading from the very second it starts. i want to add that if you *can't* see this ending coming from about eighty billion miles away you have no clue how to read film and should probably stick to dick and jane primers.i also thought it was slightly ridiculous that instead of having the dread 'magic negro' stereotype--which is just as offensive--we get the 'magic retard' stereotype. both types of characters are blessed with the ability to see the truth and speak it, to be the only honestly good (even saintly) characters in a film, and so on. can we please get past this crap? both studio heads and movie audiences are so dumbed down that they watch a film like this and see magic where there is none. it's just far enough away from mainstream BS that it makes people think they're watching something compelling when in fact they're wasting their time. it's not art. it's not compelling. it's a fair-to-middling story dressed up as art.it always shocks me that junk like this takes academy awards while directors like David lynch and todd solondz get nothing--it's just idiotic. who is really advancing the art of film-making? it's not billy bob thornton, i can tell you that. a terribly boring film with some moments of interest. that's about it.

reviews.review_title: It definately lives up to the hype
reviews.content: Unlike the English Patient, which I felt was highly overrated, I think that this film in 1996 did deserve the attention it got.  Because this is a very good movie (one of the best of 96) by having the films strength not at the climax, but in the long stretch of the film.  It is quite uplifting to see BB Thornton and his team at work in this film.The story (though very shortly explained in the short Some Folks Call It a Sling Blade) has a retarted though simple man (Thornton is exceptional as this guy) who gets released from a mental home after 25 years after he killed his mother and her lover.  Soon, be befriends a boy, and so on and so on (if I went on, it would be spoiled).  A very good script, fine direction and quite good acting bring this film to be what it is- BB Thornton's best film yet and also for members of the cast (some of them). A+

reviews.review_title: Ladies and gentleman, Mr. Billy Bob Thornton
reviews.content: SLING BLADE (1996) **** Billy Bob Thornton, Dwight Yoakam, John Ritter, Lucas Black, Natalie Canerday, J.T. Walsh, Robert Duvall. Thornton (who also directed and wrote the film's Oscar winning screenplay, based on another medium - a smaller film he produced) is a nuanced marvel as a mildly mentally retarded man whose release from a mental institute, after serving 25 years for killing his mother and her lover, forces him to cope with rehabilitation and living in the all too real world as he befriends a young boy and his mother, who are abused by her live in alcoholic redneck loser boyfriend (Yoakam in a vividly memorable, hateful performance) who provides more than a challenge for survival.Endearing and harrowingly blended perfectly with no sugar coating or easy answers. Look for filmmaker Jim Jarmusch as a fast food clerk

The only word needed to describe this movie is wow. What a powerful peice of work that starts Billy Bob Thorton in his near perfect performnace as a "simple" man who was put in a loony bin for killing his mother and her lover with a sling blade. He is then released but has nowhere to go as everything has changed. He gets a job fixing lawn mowers and such and sleeps in the garage untill he befriends a young boy and moves in with his family, just to bad his mothers boyfriend is a violent, alcholic red neck how does everything in his power to make them seem out of place. John Ritter is also very well in his role as the mothers gay friend who wants nothing more but to see the family not get hurt. The amazing script won Thronton an Oscar and the direction makes this extremly power film often dark and sometimes disturbing. The end is shocking and very brutal and will have veiwers eyes glued to the screen as the whole story unfolds right up until the credits role. Not to be missed.

reviews.review_title: Quite simply, the greatest movie I have ever seen.
reviews.content: Lyrically beautiful, wrenchingly tragic and hauntingly gothic, this is quite simple the most flawless and brilliant movie I have ever seen. It won a single Oscar (best adapted screenplay). It should have won just about every one, except best actress since it lacks a lead female role (that award went quite rightly to Frances McDormand in the Coen Brothers' riotous, suspenseful and breathtaking Fargo, the second-best movie ever). See it.

reviews.review_title: Great performance by Billy Bob Thornton
reviews.content: This movie would be average if it was not for the performance of Billy Bob Thornton, who portrays a retarded ex-convict. He lifts the movie to excellence, and I am amazed how he can develop a speech impediment as convincing as he does.I find it tough luck that he did not win the academy award, which was won by Geoffrey Rush for his (also excellent) performance in Shine.Any other year Billy Bob would have won - I reckon.

reviews.review_title: Very uninteresting, and feels like a procedural video for the criminally insane.
reviews.content: Maybe someone growing up in the South will get this. But I just found it to be slow-paced and annoying. The entire movie can be summed up in the interview with Karl at the beginning, which ends where it began, in the mental institution. It was obvious from the beginning what was gonna happen in the end. This kind of strikes a chord with me, but is too slow and boring. Some of the dialogue is stupid. It's just the usual, "go here, do that, to set up the next scene," type of movie.

With so many comments on such an excellent movie I am not sure if I can say anything new; nevertheless, an unlikely cast that really made the movie, and just the right amount of sick dialog and seediness made Sling Blade a fantastic watch. A great story! Cudos for Jack Tripper!

I was annoyed by the messages of this film. I didn't like the way it was set up so that a murder seemed justified, and the murderer a hero. (I hope it makes the Norwegian commenter feel better to know that a woman agrees with him). Strangely, despite a whole scene that pointed up the murder victim's weak spots, other characters thought that he could only be stopped by death, and the filmmaker seemed to take a positive view of the killing. I also thought the film made an odd and heavy-handed anti-abortion statement, though I have since been told that I misinterpreted that part of the dialogue (I can't be sure, since I don't really feel the need to watch the film again). However, though I had issues with the movie, I still thought that the characters were refreshing when compared with typical Hollywood fare. I also liked the Jim Jarmusch cameo. If you like intense characters and stories, you might like it.

reviews.review_title: "I don't reckon I got no reason to kill nobody. Mmm. " - Karl (Billy Bob Thorton)
reviews.content: After watching Billy Bob Thorton's feature debut 'Sling Blade' I gained an immense amount of respect for the performer. Before then I felt Thorton was kind of an average actor who was just lucky, but after seeing his incredible performance, direction and writing in 1996's 'Sling Blade' I can tell you that he is one talented guy. Thorton does an impeccable job playing Karl, a mentally-challenged deep-talking man who is released from a mental hospital after being placed there for murdering his mother and her lover when he was a child. Outside, Karl gets a job as a mechanic and befriends a 12-year-old boy Frank (Lucas Black). Frank and his mom are living a seemingly happy existence, until it all goes to hell because of Frank's mom's sick, twisted and abusive boyfriend Doyle (Dwight Yokam) who has threatened murder Frank's mom if she ever tried to leave him. Will Karl be able to maybe save his buddy Frank and his mom from this raving lunatic? Rent it, and see. The film also stars the late-great John Ritter in an excellent performance as Frank's mom's best friend who struggles with being gay, J.T. Walsh as a mentally-disturbed homicidal/rapist maniac who tries to befriend Karl in the mental hospital, and Robert Duvall in a short but none-the-less great part as Karl's long-lost hateful father. Dwight Yokam plays a perfect villain while Lucas Black is very impressive as Frank. I recommend this film very highly if you don't mind seeing kind of a downer. 'Sling Blade' received two Academy Award nominations, one for Best Actor in a Leading Role - Thorton and one for for Best Adapted Screenplay - which it actually ended up winning. 'Sling Blade' is worth watching just on the fact that Thorton gives one of the best handicapped performances of all time in it. Grade: B+MADE MY TOP 300 LIST AT #181

I liked this movie about a mentally retarded man who is sprung from an institution (he was committed there for a murder) after twenty years and forms new relationships with other people, notably a young boy and a gay man. Billy Bob Thornton's performance really carries this film, and I guarantee you will like it.*** out of ****

reviews.review_title: Some folks call it a Kaiser Blade...
reviews.content: This movie is on my top 10 favorite movies of all time. I watched this 10 years ago, I was 10 and I grew up watching this movie with my grandma...kinda weird and strange huh? We loved this film so much. Anyone who is a fan of Billy Bob Thornton should check this film out, it is in my opinion, Thorntons best movie of all time. It has a lot of story, which you don't see these days, thats another reason why I love this film. The characters are engrossing and charismatic, I've watched this film over 10 times and it still gets more interesting each time I watch it. So, if you wanna watch a great film, don't just read a review, go out and decide on your own, definitely worth a look.

I hate overused cliches, but this movie truly deserves the accolade "If you watch one movie this year......"Billy Bob Thornton earns my greatest respect for his portrayal of Carl, a mentally retarded simpleton in redneck country. His moving performance is flawless, from his mannerisms to his voice and posture. His performance is truly on a par, at least, with Dustin Hoffman's Raymond in "Rain Man" Quite apart from his acting, he also wrote and directed this movie, which ranks in my top ten films of all time at present - A powerful touching drama which dares to combine themes of mental illness, homosexuality and instituationalised prejudice to produce an outstanding and emotionally charged work of art.Every good movie needs a bad guy. Enter Dwight Yoakam, perfectly cast as Doyle, the unstable alcoholic - I certainly wouldn't like to spend too long in a room with his character unless my minders were present. Robert Duvall makes a brief, but quality performance as Carl's father.How would I summarize this movie? That's simple.....Watch it - you won't be disappointed.

A simpleton who as a boy killed his Mom and her lover, 30 years later is released from the mental hospital and integrated, so to speak, into society. Of course, the machinations of the state governments being the pieces of junk they are, he is basically just thrown away and stumbles into a dysfunctional family that mirrors his own childhood, and the fur flies!Billy Bob is probably the only good that came out of the Clinton Arkansas infestation of the 90s. This is a fine movie, with wonderful acting performances by Billy Bob and Yoakum. Ritter is pretty damn convincing as well. The story isn't too believable, or maybe I don't want to think that. I've certainly known hillbillies like Yoakum's character, but the extreme violent side that Hollywood so loves to put into every bad guy, is really an anomaly thankfully. So I think his character is just a little too over the top for me, but without him or it, of course there's no movie, so you sorta have to suffer it. There are some really great sequences, with superb writing. The way the film gradually enlightens you about the horrors of Carl's upbringing is expertly crafted. But then there are some bits that really bog the movie down, such as the obligatory 'romance' with the obligatory simple girl from the dollar store. Kind of stupid, and it really went nowheres.  And to be real nitpicky, Thornton's portrayal was a bit bizarre in that Carl at times comes across as just too wise and normal. If he's capable of displaying wit, and a decent sense of humor, why doesn't he just act like that all the time? Make sense?

reviews.review_title: Not as great as I heard
reviews.content:
I finally got "Sling Blade" yesterday at a used video store. I couldn't wait to see it. being everyone I knew had talked about it for ages.
Needless to say, I was disappointed. First by Billy Bob's portrayal of Karl. It was not convincing to me. Not like Tom Hank's Forrest Gump. You believed that he WAS Gump. I just saw Billy Bob "acting". HMMMMM.The story was interesting but nothing major. I did like the friendship between Karl and the boy. I knew what was going to happen from the moment we see the "evil" boyfriend. *******SPOILER******************* The boyfriend wasn't a nice guy but he never got abusive enough to warrant killing him. He was a weenie. All bark and no bite. He wasn't THAT bad enough to be killed, so I couldn't cheer Karl on when he did. (Not like "The Gift" when the son almost torched his dad for molesting him for years. His father WAS a pig and deserved payback!!) *******END***********************The use of a gay character as the "good" guy in the film was a pleasant surprise. Though why any gay would want to move from St. Louis to the sticks is a mystery to me. Hello, looking for trouble?? There are some good things about this movie. The cinematography was good along with that odd haunting music. There were some great acting here from Lucas Black, the boy; John Ritter, as the gay boss/friend; Robert Duvall, in a cameo as Karl's father; Dwight Yoakam(I love his music!!), as the "evil" boyfriend; and his band friends were a hoot.I can not say that I would recommend someone to buy this for their collection, I can say that it is interesting enough to rent. I really enjoyed Billy Bob's "The Gift" better.

reviews.review_title: Best movie I've seen in a long, long time
reviews.content: Being a naturally negative person, it isn't often that I comment favorably about a movie. In fact, this may be the first time.Sling Blade is an exceptionally good movie. I found this film to be a thoroughly enjoyable experience from start to finish. There is so much to appreciate here that I almost don't know where to begin--the casting, cinematography, soundtrack, plot, direction and screenplay are all, in my opinion, masterfully done. My attention was riveted from beginning to end with none of the usual Hollywood-mandated machine guns, boobs, or car chases. I can find no flaw with this movie. After seeing so many turds over the years, I really have no words to describe how utterly refreshing it is to finally see a picture of this quality come from the American Motion Picture Industry.Thank you Billy Bob Thornton for giving us Sling Blade.

I had high hopes for this film, after seeing the short that it was the inspiration for (see Some Folks call it a Sling Blade).  The short was both sad and terrifying--Karl Childers is shown as being both a traumatized individual whose childhood horrifies us and someone who terrifies us with the thought that he might be walking among us. However, in the film, the character is changed to a Charly-type: slightly mentally slow (although at times very bright and insightful which didn't seem to trouble Billy Bob Thornton as writer or directer at all) but a good hearted and kind person. The characters are all unbelievable.   The main part of the story, Karl's friendship with a young boy, is the most unbelievable part of the story--the boy is not presented as enough of  a "loser" to explain  why he would form a friendship with someone like Karl.  Ever seen this happen in real life?  In real life, he would try to raise his standing among his friends by making fun of someone like Karl. Then, we are to believe that, somehow, the mental hospital/prison Karl was in provided nothing in the way of transition living, but somehow he learned small engine repair there well enough to be given a job by (an unbelievably good) person.  Despite being institutionalized most of his life and living in a hole the rest of it, Karl somehow has obtained job skills that would be the envy of many employers.  That's believable? Then, after knowing him for only a few days, Karl informs the boy's mother that he was in prison for murdering two people--including his mother.  The boy's mother reacts as if Karl just told her he was in jail for writing a bad check.  I don't care how nice a person you are, you would be concerned about this and would certainly limit your child's time with someone like this--wouldn't you?  That's believable? Then there is the mother's boyfriend who, in contrast to everybody else in the movie who seems to be a refugee from the set of the Andy Griffith Show, makes Hannibal Lector look like someone who you'd like to see your daughter dating.  He is so one-dimensionally bad that he, too, isn't believable.  You know what is going to happen in the film after about 2 minutes of seeing him.  All you do is wait to see how it happens.  No surprises there! Want another example of how unbelievable the story is? The little hole that Karl dug to sleep in is still nicely preserved in the back shed--even has all the junk conveniently piled around it when he goes back to see it 25 years later.  25 years later?  Junk everywhere, but the little hole is still the way it was? The directing is terrible--just once it would have been nice to see a close-up shot of the actors--just to see if they can really act.  Thorton's acting, powerful in the short film, becomes downright silly as the mannerisms which made him sad and terrifying in the short, seem to occur only sporadically in the movie version. The film is a trite view of the trauma of horrible child abuse and the difficulties people with mental disabilities have coping with life. Do yourself a favor.  See the short--skip the film.

When I rented this movie on video,it was because I am a Lucas Black fan.
I went into watching this movie not knowing what to expect since I never saw it released to theatres in the town I was living in back then.Billy Bob Thornton did a fine job writing, directing and starring in a movie that should eventually turn into a classic.

In my whole life i can remember only one movie i walked out of and that was Sling Blade.The reason was that Billy Bob Thornton's delivery of the script and to this date i'm unsure what the whole ordeal was about. However, i do remember that we were three people who almost at the same time voiced our concern about the movie and expressed the desire to leave the theater.When i think about it now Sling Blade was slightly ahead of it's time. Lars von Trier championed such movies that would make you uncomfortable and gets endless critical acclaim for it.Nothing more to add, this one simply didn't work out for me.

reviews.review_title: A Crowning Achievement for Billy Bob Thornton
reviews.content:
There are those born into this world with a seemingly endless capacity for `life'-- those with the mental wherewithal and ability to embrace and appreciate the endless bounties that nature has to offer.  And then there are those less fortunate; those who lack that acuity of mind and must content themselves with more immediate pleasures, like simply drawing breath in a world that has judged and declared them an accident of birth and has summarily withdrawn it's promise to them, deeming them somehow unworthy, and subsequently refusing to offer them more than the basic sustenances of survival, viewing them too often as so much refuse, with no intrinsic value whatsoever.  An abhorrent philosophy, to be sure, and yet one too often embraced by those better equipped, those who should know better and who should make it their business to reach out and at the very least attempt to discover what even the least among us has to offer, and to offer something in return.  It's a proposition put forth by writer/director/star Billy Bob Thornton, in `Sling Blade,' an emotionally charged drama that seeks out the best within the least of us.  And finds it.After spending his entire adult life in a mental institution because of a crime he committed as a child, Karl Childers (Thornton) has been declared `well,' and is released from the `nervous hospital' (as he calls it) that has been his home these many years.  Born `simple,' the product of morally deficient parents, Karl neither demands nor expects anything from life; indeed, he wouldn't know how to.  His is a life devoid of hopes or dreams, as in point of fact, these are things he does not know even exist.  From the moment of his birth up until the day he entered the institution, Karl's life has been nothing more than a stoic and innate quest for survival.  And now, thrown back into the world, he returns to the small Arkansas town where he grew up.When Karl gets to town and steps off the bus, he is alone and with nowhere to go.  Hungry, he soon discovers the joys of `french fried potaters,' which he gets at a fast food joint.  Circumstances then bring him into contact with a twelve-year-old boy, Frank (Lucas Black), and the two quickly `make friends,' in the purest sense, thanks to Frank's intuitive response, generated by the non judgmental innocence of youth, which allows the boy to see Karl as a person, rather than as an object of disdain.  And this simple act of friendship awakens in Karl something he has never known.  For the first time, perhaps, Karl has a reason to be.Billy Bob Thornton is an enigma; Offstage, he seems perpetually attached to controversy, while as an artist, he never ceases to amaze.  As an actor/filmmaker he has consistently demonstrated true genius, which has never been more apparent than with this film, in which he presents a perspective on life that issues from a depth of staggering proportions. With this story of perfect imperfection, he indicates the possibility that a perfect world can be achieved through the efforts of imperfect people; but that, unfortunately, those who deem themselves as `perfect' must also participate, which results in a world that is ultimately and unavoidable imperfect, and in a way that is forever unalterable.  We are stuck with what we have, then, but the film's message is clear:  we do have choices; and as such, the imperfect can have a positive impact-- through care and understanding, the world can at least be a better place. 
It's a dramatic statement to make, and Thornton makes it directly, through the insightful presentation of his characters, all of whom are sharply drawn, honest and definitive, and with situations and dialogue that rings true throughout the film.  Still, some of the most telling moments are found in the silence of Karl's reflections; those `moments' that allow the viewer to process and digest the drama of the story as it unfolds, and which adds depth to the overall perspective of how Karl views the world, and how the world views Karl.On the surface, Karl seems as enigmatic as his creator, but it's a perception due mainly to Karl's retiring, undemonstrable countenance, born of the incessant repression of his spirit and any and all vestiges of the humanity alive within him but unable to break free.  In Karl, Thornton has created a character who is something of a study in contradiction, a complex individual who at his core is actually quite simple and uncomplicated, yet possessed of deep-seated emotions fettered by the constraints of his environment and his lack of mental proficiency.  And Thornton so ably conveys the depth of Karl's feelings-- emotions he is so desperately trying to understand and express-- that he becomes oddly endearing and readily evokes the empathy of the audience.  Without question, this is Thornton's most emotionally powerful performance ever, for which he deservedly earned an Oscar nomination for Best Actor (in a year in which Geoffrey Rush took home the gold for `Shine').  Director Thornton supported his dynamic portrayal of Karl by extracting some extraordinary performances from his terrific cast of actors, beginning with the work of young Lucas Black, who presents Frank in terms that are altogether natural and unassuming.  Dwight Yoakam, too, elicits a highly emotional response by creating a character, Doyle Hargraves, who is absolutely insufferable; this is the guy you love to hate.  And John Ritter is effective as the supportive Vaughan Cunningham, turning in a performance that is quite real and convincing, as does Natalie Canerday, as Frank's mother, Linda.Also notable in supporting roles are J.T. Walsh, as one of Karl's fellow mental patients, a loathsome individual named Charles Bushman; James Hampton, as Jerry, the director of the institution; Rick Dial, as Bill Cox; and Brent Briscoe as Scooter Hodges.  A remarkable and unforgettable film, `Sling Blade' is a journey of emotional discovery that is absorbing and absolute.  10/10.

Billy Bob Thornton's intense, nuanced portrayal of the profoundly damaged Karl Childers is what made Charlize Theron's Eileen Wournos possible - a total and flawlessly sustained transformation that urges the viewer to think long and hard about the definition of both criminality and mental illness, helping us understand that murdering someone doesn't necessarily make one a murderer, just as limited intellectual ability doesn't make one 'handicapped'. With nary a trace of the sentimentalism or showboating that plagues similar interpretations (Hoffman's 'Rain Man', Penn's 'I Am Sam'), I found Thornton's Karl to be one of the most lovable characters in all of cinema. So, if your empathy muscles are getting slack from too many oversimplified good/evil, black/white mega-fables, watch this film. It'll leave you not just feeling, but KNOWING that life is really just one big gray area, and that every one of us is an exception to the rule.

My comments:  Billy Bob's jutting chin & that facial tic; just superb characterization.  I saw this movie when it was new.  Amazed about performance of B.B.; really cared for this character & how how he was treated.  Still amazing that the old 'Boo Radley' (Duvall) played BB's father.  Duvall was so chilling in 'Mockingbird'; he scared me so much I never saw any more of his movies until 'Sling Blade'.  . . .  Forgive me, I'm one of those unfamous actresses with lots of training . . . John Ritter *really* playing a gay guy this time, LOL (shades of Three's Company). More musings:  never thought a guy named Billy Bob would be a Hollywood star, but who woulda known?  Billy Bob (Karl, I must say) was really cool.  He really cleaned the clock of the bad guy in this movie, so super cool (I'm redundant), then from what I can remember off he goes back again to the mental slammer.  Dwight Yoakam -- a boy from our home town, here (Columbus, Ohio), or so they say.  I didn't know he was an actor.  He gave a very good performance in this movie.  He was so snarlingly wise-ass convincing as the fiance of the boy's mother.  This movie gets a 10.  Any movie where I can watch the whole thing from beginning to end (& many of them are difficult for me), gets a *perfect".

reviews.review_title: A Bit Odd, But Pretty Good
reviews.content: Karl Childers (Billy Bob Thornton), a simple man hospitalized since his childhood murder of his mother and her lover, is released to start a new life in a small town.Kevin Thomas wrote that the film is "a mesmerizing parable of good and evil and a splendid example of Southern storytelling at its most poetic and imaginative." Now, exactly what "Southern storytelling" is remains a bit unclear, though this seems to be a common refrain. The good and evil aspects are certainly there.Billy Bob's character is sort of the gruff, pirate version of Forrest Gump. This makes for a strange mix and not everyone is going to find the character convincing. Often he comes across as annoying. But, indeed, perhaps that is exactly how a mentally disabled person would project themselves?

"Sling Blade" is the touching story of a mildly retarded man's freindship with a fatherless boy. All is well until his mother's abusve boyfreind, played by Dwight Yokam, comes into the picture. The film is beautifly photographed, acted, and written. I strongly recommend it.

Billy Bob Thornton wrote, directed, and starred in "Sling Blade," a 1996 film that features Dwight Yoakam, John Ritter, Lucas Black, and Robert Duvall.Thornton is Karl, a slightly retarded man who lives in the state hospital since murdering his mother and her lover. He believed at the time that his mother was being raped, and when he realized that she wasn't, he killed her as well. His childhood was horrible, filled with isolation and cruelty.It's time for Karl to be released, and the head of the hospital (James Hampton), knowing Karl has nowhere to go, gets him a job fixing small machines, at which he's an expert. He can also stay in the back of the store. Karl befriends a young boy, Frank (Black), who lives with his young, widowed mother. Karl moves into their garage. Unfortunately, Frank's mother has an abusive boyfriend, Doyle (Yoakam) who makes life hard for the sensitive Frank. She also has a gay friend (John Ritter) who looks out for both of them.Karl thrives in the outside world, becoming more vocal and even making eye contact with people he's speaking with occasionally. The only problem is Doyle, who is a mean drunk and a generally awful person.A fantastic character study of a basically gentle person who is befriended by others because they sense that, despite what he did, he is a simple, good, and caring man. It's a story of people who overlook eccentricities and reach out to him.You can see the denouement coming from a mile away, but that's not really the point of the movie. It's about what society can do to a person, both good and bad.There is no way to adequately describe the acting, which is remarkable. Bill Bob Thornton is so natural as Karl, one forgets it's a performance, as he sits rubbing his hands together and grunting, looking away when he's talking. John Ritter as Vaughan, the gay friend of Frank and his mother, is remarkable. I didn't recognize him at first.The film is filled with poignancy as well as some great humor. It's a very warm movie, despite the offbeat subject matter.Highly recommended. A real tour de force for Thornton, and an excellent film all around.

reviews.review_title: The only thing wrong with this movie...
reviews.content: Is that Dwight Yoakam, J.T. Walsh, John Ritter, Lucas Black (II), Natalie Canerday and every single other person in this movie did not get nominated from some type of Award or Honor. This is without a doubt one of the Best movies of the 90's. Simply outstanding! When a movie makes you FORGET what you thought about someone when you walk in (i.e. Ritter, Yoakam) and you actually BELIVE in the characters...it's more than done "its' job". I really don't think there is EVEN ONE spot in this movie that I can find and say "AH"...to point out a fault! I wish more Directors were this creative, orignial, simply OUTSTANDING! Thank you Billy Bob Thornton! I hope "Bad Santa" is just as GREAT!
Brilliant. A tragic fable of kindness that can't quite let the sins of evil go.

reviews.review_title: A very moving and powerful film
reviews.content: Sling Blade is on of the most hypnotic films I have seen in awhile. The atmosphere in this film is powerful and the performances seem more natural than acting, as if you're watching a documentary and not an entertaining motion picture. Billy Bob Thornton has sculpted an absolutely beautiful movie from his original screenplay and it's a film you won't soon forget. Thornton's performance is also very good, but the film belongs to Lucas Black, Dwight Yoakam and John Ritter. All three of these actors turn in completely believable performances that are at times funny and heart-breaking. The cinematography from Barry Markowitz is beautiful and the music from Daniel Lanois is also great. The film is told not through images so much as in great dialog and awesome writing. Sling Blade is a film you will never forget.

reviews.review_title: Great acting and great idea spoiled by a mediocre script
reviews.content: This movie could have been one of the best movies of the last decade or so. It had a great characterization done by Billy Bob Thornton of a semi-retarded man freed from jail. Unfortunately, all the great potential was destroyed by a poor and inconsistent script. The first sign of flaw was when Thornton's character explained why he was jailed. It was understandable that he killed a man who he believed threatened his Mom and family. However, then he killed his Mom. This made no sense, and indicated that he was a psycho, whom we should not pity. The filmmakers were trying to portray the man in a sensitive light, but in the end they failed. The other characters in the movie were poorly explained. The late John Ritter plays a gay man in a small Arkansas town, who feels a duty to protect a woman and her boy from her boyfriend (Dwight Yoachim). When Ritter's character first meets Thornton's character there is very clear fear of this retarded man on his part. All the fears and stereotypes are there. After Ritter reveals to the retarded man that he is gay, he falls apart and becomes totally empathetic. This makes no sense. The gay man would probably still feel threatened and suspicious until he got to know the retarded man better. The Mom is poorly explained. Whom is she? Whom was her husband? What was he like? Why was she so pacific, and took so much from her boyfriend? What was up with her son? He seemed depressed and like he didn't have any friends? Why was this? These things are never explained. The boyfriend (Yoachim) is poor and stereotypically portrayed. He is the bad guy, abusive boyfriend. No attempt is given to explain why, and even much about why he is a threat to justify the ending of the film. Why were the cops never called in? Even in backwoods Arkansas, in the 90s cops are called at some point. The filmmakers could have at least showed that the cops were overburden and apathetic. At least the cops could have made an appearance and basically did nothing. Why wasn't there more suspicion about the retarded man? He killed his Mom for no really justifiable reason. Why let a "dangerous" man walk around with your boy? That isn't today's World. People are absolutely nuts about these kind of things. Basically, they all just trusted the guy. They also know that he killed a man because he thought he was a danger to his family. Okay. So, let the guy stay in a dysfunctional home with a violent tempered boyfriend. That's a one way ticket to a repeat. This is what I would have done differently. I would have cut out the killing of his Mom. It makes Thornton's character less to feel sorry about. I would have not had the killing of the boyfriend at the end. I would have had Thornton's character make a conscientious decision to not resort to violence again. The ending would have been much more meaningful if Thornton's character restrains himself, and the police arrive late to a scene where the boyfriend kills the Mom and her boy. That would have caused the audience to really think about the issue of domestic violence. After all, this was an "art film". Why have the sell-out Hollywood ending. I really think with more work this could have been a masterpiece. Unfortunately, it turned out to be an average film.

reviews.review_title: A movie which proves that anyone with a Hollywood idea can sell out.
reviews.content: In a television interview prior to its release, Billy Bob Thornton explained that the idea of 'Sling Blade' began when he was depressed about a four line part he had in an earlier movie. (To my knowledge, he meant the Jim Jarmusch movie "Dead Man", in a cameo as one of the nomadic drifters)  From then on, Thornton then claimed to have looked into the mirror with a strange facial expression, and talked to himself in a "grunted voice," similar to that of Karl Childers. He said this gave him the idea for the melodramatic yet highly overrated film, "Sling Blade." But I don't only see the idea coming from that. The plot, at least in my opinion, seemed like an amalgram of several earlier (and better) movies, like David and Lisa, One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest, and Edward Scissorhands. The feeling of nothingness from playing a miniscule part in a movie is one thing, but a familiar plot, with cliches galore, is another.The film did have good performances, however, particularly the leads, but the "villainy" of Dwight Yoakam as Doyle was weak and unconvincing. Add some kudos to chilling atmosphere and an unpredictable ending, but expect an aftertaste shortly after in which you know you just saw a reworking of another idea, told in a different way, and in a different setting.If you want a sugar-sweet sentimental tearjerker, I'd recommend it. If you want something new, you picked the wrong movie.

"Sling Blade" is an amazing film. Billy Bob Thorton is great! This film is brillaint! The movie is very touching and very enjoyable. This film was very good, and I recommend it. Billy Bob Thorton is brillaint! I give it an 8 out of 10! :)

reviews.review_title: Slow moving movie saved by Yoakum
reviews.content: Billy bob thornton plays a dimwitted dood who killed his mother decades ago but has just been released from the loony bin into a small town where he develops into the wisest and most loved man in town! I just can't buy that. This guy would be an outcast wherever he lived.Movie is saved by a memorable villainous role from hillbilly singer dwight yoakum of all people. He's the town bully and is so obnoxious you have to admire him. I loved the scene where he throws his "friends" out of the house cause he says they're losers. "Git yer butts outa my house!!" He must have said that 10 times. And hell - it wasn't even his house; belonged to his girl friend! Next day he tries to apologize but ends up insulting everybody again. Bill Murray is great at playing normal/rotten people and apparently yoakum can do it too.The late John Ritter is unrecognizable as a gay store manager and is great as is the kid who plays thornton's pal. Good show but pretty predictable.

reviews.review_title: Should have been nominated for an Academy Award
reviews.content: If anyone wants to see great acting, directing,editing, and casting,they should see this movie. Faultless acting throughout but especially brilliant performance by Billy Bob Thornton. Had this movie had a bigger box office, then he would have gotten at least a nomination, as well as the movie getting a "Best Picture" nomination. The movie starts out in low key where many might stop watching. But the movie has a kind of addictive quality as familiarization with the characters takes hold. Great example of the quality of movie that Hollywood can make when box office isn't the prime goal.

I have just watched Sling Blade, and I was really impressed.I didn't expect much from Billy Bob Thornton, but I was wrong. His performance is one of the best I've ever seen, he deserved an Oscar for this work. He is of course not the whole movie, but his performance as Karl Childers was just fantastic. I will from now on have a lot of respect for Mr. Thornton.The rest of the cast also performed very well, maybe I should mention the performance by Dwight Yoakam, he really performed well in the evil role.You won't have the same feeling after watching this as you had after watching Forrest Gump, but you will be touched.I would rate this movie 8/10, but it is almost 9/10.

reviews.review_title: Weak second half and predictable finish...
reviews.content: This film had all the potential to be one of the best of all time. But at the end it failed. Why? Because it was predictable. The first half was very emotional and substantial that it almost touched perfection. But after some part it was like you could see what is going to happen. And not only did it happen but it was almost forced by the most unnatural way. The step father was yelling to be killed like it was his intention. And honestly who ever stands so cool and self- possessed in front of his murderer who's moving towards him with a sling blade at his hands? The film itself gave me great expectations which collapsed soon. It could and should be better.

I'm sorry, but the plot, content, and yes, even the acting in this film left me feeling just plain disappointed.Maybe I was influenced by the fact that I had already seen Billy Bob Thornton in a number of later movies before renting this one.  So I already knew him to be an intelligent and talented actor.Now, to see him pucker-up his face in mimic of a severe underbite, stare off in the distance repeatedly mumbling, "I reckon, ummm-hmmm" and suddenly, wow, I'm so convinced that he's a mentally-challenged murderer?The way he portrays this character is just outright corny.John Ritter, a brilliant actor, in this performance shows all the signs of struggling with a bad script and poor direction.The one shining star in this film is Dwight Yoakum.  He is most convincing as the menacing, abusive, alcoholic boyfriend.The ending, however, can only be described as trite.

It won all those awards including an Oscar... which shocks me. ABC showed it tonight and I had to force myself to sit through this endless, painfully slow-paced drama about a retarded man in a town peopled by dumb rednecks. Oh, dear... how boring can a film get?   Sorry, Billy Bob Thornton, but this just wasn't my cup of tea!

This is one of those movies that you either love or hate, and either get or don't get.  It takes at least a couple of viewings to really understand the Thornton character.  But, once you do understand him, you kinda understand his thinking, and the truths he uses to get through his life.  The chemistry between Thornton and Lucas Black is very good.  I also liked the John Ritter character, and I DO NOT like John Ritter.  Overall, a movie that everybody should see at least once.

Sometimes a hero comes from the most unlikely place."Sling Blade," the 1996 film written and directed by and starring Billy Bob Thornton, is not an easy film to watch. It's subject matter is serious and nearly every moment of the film is either emotionally intense or so perfectly paced that the film plays with this overwhelming anxiety hanging over it at all times. Then, there's the matter of Thornton's channeling of Karl, a simple man released after years in a "hospital," where he was placed following the murder of his mother and her lover when Karl was 12. It's so deliberate, so intense and so hypnotic that even watching the film becomes a physically exhausting experience.Thornton's Karl is, apparently, a gentle man with an emotionally intense core. One can never be sure whether his slow, deliberate nature is completely a result of his slower intelligence or his guarded, fractured emotions. The fact that this is so challenging to decide is a tribute to Thornton's balanced, insightful performance.Despite Karl's obvious lackings in intelligence, he gets a job fixing small motors, befriends a boy named Frank, and is eventually invited by Frank's mother, Linda (Natalie Canerday), to live in the family's garage. Conflict erupts from her jealous, redneck boyfriend Doyle (Dwight Yoakam) and, well, the rest simply must be seen."Sling Blade" captured the Best First Feature prize for Thornton from the Independent Spirit Awards, along with a screenplay award at the Oscars. While Thornton's performance was Oscar-nominated, somehow the Academy thought there was a better performance in 1996 from a Male Actor. They were wrong.Likewise, the lack of a nomination for the powerful, focussed performance of country singer Dwight Yoakam is almost impossible to fathom. Yoakam sizzles here in portraying a boyfriend who can, at the flip of a cowboy hat, be tender and paternal then abusive and jealous. It's a tremendous performance."Sling Blade" is, without a doubt, one of the best independent films ever made with a near perfect combination of strong script, focused direction, solid performances down to the smallest role, and beautiful cinematography. Sadly, it suffered the fate of last year's "The Woodsman," a stellar film limited by its intimidating, well presented subject matter and with performances so strong the film is "too much" for your general filmgoing audience."Sling Blade" is one of those "must see" films for true connoisseurs of film. It is not a film that every connoisseur will absolutely adore, but it is a film that simply begs to be seen by those who respect the craft of filmmaking. "Sling Blade" is exhausting yet exhilarating, troubling yet insightful, and powerful yet numbing. "Sling Blade" is a film you may not embrace, but I guarantee you will not forget.

reviews.review_title: Two hours of happy ending movie with a not-happy ending
reviews.content: When i watched the movie this evening i didn't know anything about it at all. So i was in a good mood after the start of the film was quite well done. It had false hints, a main character that seems almost unique and a really promising introduction into the plot. So i thought this might be about a retard that isn't as lucky in life as Forrest Gump is. But i thought wrong. After the good start the movie just went a horrible way. Everything turned out sooooooooo nicely for that poor guy Karl, people forgave him his murdering, he got a job, everyone was sooooooooo friendly and accepted him. The homosexual guy trusts him so quickly and tells Karl how he can't do an outing. He and the poooooooooor kiddo get best friends. Problem is, this continues almost two hours. It was like a terrible happy ending all over the movie. Next problem, i didn't wonder about the ending at all, when he kills that bad bad bad boyfriend. In fact i was hoping all movie long that he would do that. So maybe this this whole happy story was about to let us not think, that Karl would murder again. But this attempt completely failed. Well i was once working with retarded children and i loved that job, so i don't think that Billy Bob Thornton's acting was very good. If you want to see a brilliant performance, then watch Rainman with Dustin Hoffman. Also Forrest Gump does so much better regarding acting of the main character. But Thornton's acting was surely the best of this movie. The other actors in Sling Blade were pretty much worse. Totally plain and stereotype characters. The homosexual that doesn't like violence at all. The Mother, that can't get away from her bad boyfriend. The other retarded girl. I really didn't like any character at all. To sum it all up i liked the beginning and i was hoping for a really good and interesting story, but after a while of good hope i had to realize how bad this plot actually is.

There are more than a few similarities between "Forrest Gump" and "Sling Blade". The worse being external: "Forrest Gump" won best picture and "Sling Blade" did not. "Sling Blade" has got to be one of the finest films I have seen from the last twenty-five years. It's strengths are many and it's post-end-credits effects numerous. There is a lot that can be learned from those who live a much more simple lives than ourselves, and Thornton's Karl is just the type of person who has something to teach us. Through a very dark subject matter ridden film there is a perfectly meticulous pacing and some priceless humor. Most of all, however, there exists a love for life and a hope of understanding one another. This is a life altering film.

reviews.review_title: Thought provoking but 30 minutes too long.
reviews.content: This movie was too long, too dull and too tedious.  The characters may have been real people but that gave the actors no reason to be so boring in their portrayals.  The man/boy friendship was simply unbelievable.  The resolution of the movie contradicted the heart of the whole morality tale that I thought the movie was about, and though I respect such a painful twist, I also find it disturbing to think that my fellow watchers found it a satisfying ending with a clear conscience.  Thought-provoking but sleep-inducing.
Over-rated, feeble-minded dreck, weighed down by awkward expositional writing, cloying sentimentality and pseudo-profundity.

Sling Blade, in my opinion, is much better than Forrest Gump, simply because it is more realistic, more honest, and more serious. This film tackles some heavy issues, such as whether or not it is alright to kill someone if it's for a good cause. This allows the film to be a haunting experience. Billy Bob Thornton deserved his Oscar for his screenplay. He should have also won the Oscar for Best Actor, too. His performance is one of the greatest that I have ever seen. Lucas Black, Dwight Yoakam, John Ritter, and Robert Duvall bring so much to their characters. You feel like you know them. Thorton directed it masterfully. His choice in music heightens the mood, and also contrasts it in some way, which makes it work perfectly. This film shall forever stand the test of time.

reviews.review_title: Billy Bob Thornton's triumph! It is simply fascinating!
reviews.content: Billy Bob Thornton portrays a disturbed, mentally ill man that is let out of prison after 25 years for the killing two people including his mother. A stunning performance that should have won him the Oscar but did not. The fact that this was a low budget film didn't matter as excellent casting provided characters that are believable and memorable. Among them, A young Lucas Black is exceptional as a twelve year old boy who befriends "Carl". Dwight Yoakam proves that he is more than just a great country music singer and John Ritter plays a kind, gay friend of the family. Truly a gem of a picture.

reviews.review_title: I reckon this motion picture is good...mmm-hmm
reviews.content: The film that made Billy Bob Thornton. Sling Blade brought out the best in him and this is Billy Bob sans Mr. Woodcock sans School for Scoundrels and whatever low class comedy he's made. He took a challenging dramatic role and he nails it in the coffin. I must admit, I wasn't expecting him to be this superb, I guess I underestimated the guy. Billy Bob just came out of nowhere with his explosive performance as reformed criminal/mentally challenged Karl Childers. One can only wonder how he ended up in tasteless movies and tedious comedies. Not only did he act but he also directed and wrote the film. Nothing more can be said other than, he really was passionate about this project and it shows when you see the movie. Great script, great cast and great performances all around.This is Billy Bob's shining moment and is undoubtedly the highest point of his career and credits is where credits due but you just can't help but also notice the support cast which includes Dwight Yoakam as the fiend of a step dad to a very young Lucas Black's character Frank. Black and Billy Bob glued perfectly on screen and you'll just love hating Yoakam's menacing performance. All in all, a brilliant film with powerful performances and quite possibly the best film of 1996.

Thornton has crafted a character in Karl Childers so guileless and true to himself that we instantly find ourselves on his side. We see the incongruity of trailer trash hick types that will call Karl a re-tard when they themselves have not a tenth the strength of character and goodness of heart of Karl. He does not understand the world of police, laws and the justice system but he has read the bible and recons he understands a great deal of it. He recognizes a kindred good heart in 'that boy' and his mother.
  Karl knows the evil side of people perhaps better than we do, being raised as he was and having been made sport of quite a bit. (probably a vast understatement by him) When he is faced with a choice of what to do when people he has come to love are in danger, what would a person like Karl do, think of himself? I am in awe of Thorntons characterisation in Karl. Billy Bob is unrecognizable and the character is striking and unique. While John Wayne was an acclaimed actor, it mattered not what role he was playing be it Rooster Cogburn or Gengis Khan he was always John Wayne, same same. Billy Bob as Karl Childers is acting defined. No actor is to be seen and there is this remarkable fellow name-a Karl Childers in his place. Outstanding tale and deserving nothing less than 10.

reviews.review_title: "They say they're settin' me free today"
reviews.content: One rainy afternoon, four years ago, I got bored and went to rent a couple of movies.  Well, this was one of them.  I'd heard about it until I was sick of hearing the title and it had been reccommended to me by several people. Finally, I broke down and decided to watch it. I popped it in the VCR and really wasn't expecting much.  I didn't really care to see a story about some mentally retarded, backwoods hick who had been in lock-up most of his life for butchering his mother.  It just didn't sound too enchanting.  (give me a break, I was 17)Anyway, by the time Carl was halfway into giving his monologue to a wide-eyed reporter, I was too absorbed to go to the bathroom.  For the next two hours, I was on an emotional rollercoaster that no other film has ever even come close to matching.  This one just hit all the right buttons.  I was laughing and crying at the same time and when the whole thing was said and done, I just wanted to find a way to call up Billy Bob Thornton and thank him.  He made a movie that not only changed the way I felt about movies, but also, it changed a lot of the ways that I looked at life.  In short, I haven't been the same since.This is the only movie (with the exception of Fight Club) that I have ever watched all the way through, rewound it, and watched it again the same night. I just couldn't get enough of it.  Yeah, the movie had a long running time, but it just covers SO much.  It covers issues such as abortion, homosexuality, poverty, backwoods life, ignorance, fear, FRIENDSHIP, being gay in and trying to hide it in a small town, and above all, doing what you think is right and putting your own neck on the line for someone you really care about.  This film has covers everything under the sun and does it right.Over the last four years, I have shown this movie to everyone I know and I even watched it with my grandmother.  It really does have something for everyone.  Throughout it's somewhat dark tone, there is a very positive message and after seeing this, you'll never look at a mentally challenged person the same way again.  I promise you that.  Just see it.

From the sparkling mind of Billy Bob Thornton comes this send-up of the Forrest Gump school of moral philosophy: concepts so simple, only a child can understand them. Simple-minded, homicidal, biscuit-loving country boy is incarcerated in a "nervous hospital" for chopping up his adulterous mom and her lover in mid-coitus. During the several years of his rehabilitation, he achieves remarkable proficiency in small engine repair, learns to read, and fine tunes an original proclivity for righteous indignation by his dedication to independent bible study. After a favorable prognosis from hospital administration, he is released back into the rural community from whence he came. There, he discovers French Fries, lands a job "fixin" small engines, and is befriended by a few compassionate locals who allow him to reside in their garages. But such paradisaical circumstances as these are rarely lasting. It seems our hero is unable to control his religious impulses, and eventually splits a mans head in half with the blade of a lawn mower. As a consequence, he is sent back to the "nervous hospital." On the positive side, the towns small engines have never ran better.Overall message of movie: one is always justified to kill other people with various lawn implements if one has strong morals, which, coincidently, is the "fundamental" message of most religions (one can, for example, easily imagine a Muslim version of this movie). Editorial: mildly entertaining bit of acting by Thornton, Ritter, and surprisingly, Yokum. The kid who plays "Frank," however, maintains the cathartic effect by periodic appeal to the viewers (juvenile) sympathies (assisted, in large part, by tear-jerking background music).
